questions.q: Where is the pain located in Appendicitis?
questions.rationale: The appendix is located in the Right Lower Quadrant (McBurney's Point).

questions.q: Why is the Pancreatitis patient kept NPO?
questions.rationale: Eating stimulates the pancreas to secrete enzymes, which digests the pancreas itself. NPO stops this process.

questions.q: What is the most dangerous electrolyte imbalance in renal failure?
questions.rationale: Hyperkalemia (High Potassium) can cause fatal cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.q: What drug is used to lower ammonia levels in cirrhosis?
questions.rationale: Lactulose traps ammonia in the gut and expels it via stool, treating hepatic encephalopathy.

questions.q: Which food group is lowest in fiber?
questions.rationale: Animal products (meat, milk, eggs) contain no dietary fiber.

questions.q: How many calories are in 1 gram of fat?
questions.rationale: Fats are the most calorie-dense nutrient at 9 kcal/gram.

questions.q: Which food produces Acid Ash?
questions.rationale: Acid ash diets acidify urine to prevent certain stones and infections.

questions.q: Which grain is allowed on a Gluten-Free diet?
questions.rationale: Rice and Corn are gluten-free. Remember "BROW" to avoid.

questions.q: What organism commonly causes Acute Glomerulonephritis?
questions.rationale: It is an immune complex reaction that occurs weeks after a Strep throat infection.

questions.q: Which colostomy can be irrigated?
questions.rationale: Only colostomies with formed stool (lower colon) can be trained via irrigation.

questions.q: How is Hepatitis A transmitted?
questions.rationale: Hep A is viral, transmitted via contaminated food/water (Fecal-Oral).

questions.q: What assessment finding is classic for Pyloric Stenosis?
questions.rationale: The thickened pyloric muscle feels like an olive in the epigastrum.

questions.q: What is the classic sign of intussusception?
questions.rationale: Stool mixed with blood and mucus looks like currant jelly.

questions.q: What type of stool is seen in Hirschsprung's Disease?
questions.rationale: Stool is forced through the narrowed segment, appearing ribbon-like.

questions.q: What is the best position for a client with Hiatal Hernia?
questions.rationale: Gravity helps keep the stomach contents down. Sit up after meals.

questions.q: What diet prevents Dumping Syndrome?
questions.rationale: Carbs and fluids speed up emptying. Protein and fat slow it down.

questions.q: What is the priority assessment for a client with ascites?
questions.rationale: Ascites puts pressure on the diaphragm, impairing breathing.

questions.q: What is a major complication of esophageal varices?
questions.rationale: These veins are fragile and can burst, causing life-threatening bleeding.

questions.q: Why must scissors be kept at the bedside with a Blakemore tube?
options: To cut the tube if airway is blocked
questions.rationale: If the balloon moves up and blocks the airway, you must cut the tube to deflate it instantly.

questions.q: What type of diet is recommended for Ulcerative Colitis?
questions.rationale: Low residue reduces bowel volume and irritation.

questions.q: Which disease is characterized by "skip lesions"?
questions.rationale: Crohn's affects patchy areas of the GI tract, unlike UC which is continuous.

questions.q: What food should be avoided in Diverticulitis?
questions.rationale: Small seeds can get trapped in the diverticula and cause inflammation.

questions.q: Where does gallbladder pain typically radiate?
questions.rationale: Referred pain to the right shoulder is a classic sign of cholecystitis.

questions.q: What is a cardinal sign of Peritonitis?
questions.rationale: The abdomen becomes rigid due to muscle guarding against the severe inflammation.

questions.q: What EKG change is associated with Hypokalemia?
questions.rationale: U waves are a specific sign of low potassium.

questions.q: What is the first EKG sign of Hyperkalemia?
questions.rationale: Tall, peaked T waves indicate dangerous levels of potassium.

questions.q: What is a primary symptom of Hyponatremia?
questions.rationale: Sodium regulates fluid balance; low sodium causes brain swelling (cerebral edema).

questions.q: What is a common sign of Hypernatremia?
questions.rationale: High sodium draws water out of cells, causing dehydration signs.

questions.q: What signs indicate Hypocalcemia?
questions.rationale: Low calcium causes neuromuscular irritability and spasms.

questions.q: What is a symptom of Hypercalcemia?
questions.rationale: High calcium acts as a sedative on the muscles and nerves.
